text:
How would you turn an academic publication into shareable content?

One of our engineers wrote a very high-level paper that is being published in a well known journal. What can I do? Blog post, of course, translating it into language our clients will understand and offering benefits.

But what else?

elements.text:
How would you turn an academic publication into shareable content?

One of our engineers wrote a very high-level paper that is being published in a well known journal. What can I do? Blog post, of course, translating it into language our clients will understand and offering benefits.

But what else?

text:
Grab some quotables, especially if there are some stats involved. Do some research around what kind of other publications might like to use said quotable, along with a handy citation. May be a low friction way to get some backlinks

Create a 4-6 panel webcomic explaining the main thrust of the insight(s)

Create an audio version of the 'translated' article

Write a meta how-to translate academic stuff into client friendly stuff

Write a how-to _interpret_ academic stuff into insights, using your blog as the example. Continue to do this and add examples, become an authority on teaching your clients how to read through academia

text: Hey everyone - question for the e-commerce SEO experts out there! How would you approach keyword mapping/targeting for two similar(ish) products? We're trying to optimize individual pages, as we only have a handful of products... but there's a lot of overlapping keywords because they're essentially in the same category. For example, if they're both "desk chairs" or something like that. Would you try to differentiate the 2 products so they're not both competing for the parent kw "desk chair"?

elements.text: Hey everyone - question for the e-commerce SEO experts out there! How would you approach keyword mapping/targeting for two similar(ish) products? We're trying to optimize individual pages, as we only have a handful of products... but there's a lot of overlapping keywords because they're essentially in the same category. For example, if they're both "desk chairs" or something like that. Would you try to differentiate the 2 products so they're not both competing for the parent kw "desk chair"?

text: What do you see ranking? Category/collection level pages or individual product pages? I'd wager that the category-level page with content and multiple options would be the right fit if the buyer intent is high.

elements.text: What do you see ranking? Category/collection level pages or individual product pages? I'd wager that the category-level page with content and multiple options would be the right fit if the buyer intent is high.

text: Pull out stats from the paper and turn them into an infographic

elements.text: Pull out stats from the paper and turn them into an infographic

text:
Agreed with Brenden, part of this is going to be what your SEO targets are. Are you planning to get traffic through products or collections?

A `desk chair` collection does feel like it’d make sense here as a parent collection.

elements.text:
Agreed with Brenden, part of this is going to be what your SEO targets are. Are you planning to get traffic through products or collections?

A
desk chair
collection does feel like it’d make sense here as a parent collection.

text: Right now we have better rankings + traffic for the individual pages, but I believe part of that is because we haven't really put too much effort into the category pages. (I'm new to the company, so I'm just digging into the strategy now.) If we were to go that route -- i.e. going after the category-level -- would we then just not worry about optimizing anything on the product-specific pages? What are the best practices there?

elements.text: Right now we have better rankings + traffic for the individual pages, but I believe part of that is because we haven't really put too much effort into the category pages. (I'm new to the company, so I'm just digging into the strategy now.) If we were to go that route -- i.e. going after the category-level -- would we then just not worry about optimizing anything on the product-specific pages? What are the best practices there?

text: Also important to note: when I look through SERPs, there doesn't seem to be a clear winner for what competitors are doing. I'm seeing some category pages and some product pages. ("desk chairs" was just a hypothetical example, btw, not the industry I'm in :wink: )

elements.text: Also important to note: when I look through SERPs, there doesn't seem to be a clear winner for what competitors are doing. I'm seeing some category pages and some product pages. ("desk chairs" was just a hypothetical example, btw, not the industry I'm in

text:
Getting into a category focus is likely analogous to the pillar content strategy that we're starting to see more of in the SEO world.  // <https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-a-pillar-page>

The products feeding into the pillar are potentially more important on the long tail, and the pillar itself captures a broader, well, category.

So you'd be investing a lot into the pillar to rank well for "desk chairs," but also making sure lots of desk-chair related cluster content (including the 2 products) feed into it. Product A might aim to compete on something like "desk chair for a small space mid-range price" and product B "desk chair affordable with wheels"

Something to noodle on!

attachments.title: What Is a Pillar Page? (And Why It Matters For Your SEO Strategy)
attachments.text: The way people search has changed, so your blog strategy needs to change too. Learn what a pillar page is, and how it fits into the topic cluster strategy.
attachments.fallback: What Is a Pillar Page? (And Why It Matters For Your SEO Strategy)

text: (I can't tell you if this maps perfectly for eCommerce though, so grain of salt + defer to SEO eComm specialists!)

elements.text: (I can't tell you if this maps perfectly for eCommerce though, so grain of salt + defer to SEO eComm specialists!)

text:
Products v Category v Blog Content _(e.g., posts/articles)_ v Marketing Content _(e.g., non-blog content written for a specific traffic-generating term, like ‘ROI calculator’_) is partially a strategy decision.

• Where do you want to invest the resources?
• Where do you want to be getting traffic from? 
• Where do you have an advantage?
• What is your market searching for?
Beyond that, though, I think it’s worth always worth focusing on products and collections. Leaving one or the other naked (_e.g., no collection descriptions)_ just looks bad and harms you in the search.

> If we were to go that route -- i.e. going after the category-level -- would we then just not worry about optimizing anything on the product-specific pages? What are the best practices there?
Na, it’s an ‘optimize both’ situation. A good approach here is:

• Optimizing collections for categorical terms that apply to your market/that your market is searching for (e.g., ‘<https://www.hermanmiller.com/products/seating/office-chairs/aeron-chairs/|herman miller aeron chairs>’)
• Optimizing product pages for specific product search terms that apply to your market (e.g., <https://www.hermanmiller.com/products/seating/office-chairs/mirra-2-chairs/|herman miller Mirra 2 chairs>’)
> Right now we have better rankings + traffic for the individual pages, but I believe part of that is because we haven’t really put too much effort into the category pages.
This is _super_ common. You have a nice low-hanging fruit here.

• Pick a few pages to focus on first (e.g., high AOV in that collection)
• Look at how much content is ranking on the pages ~2-4 spots above you for each page you picked
• Add more high-quality content to your individual collection descriptions. Your goal is ‘be better, on average, than they are’
• Update your internal linking to point to these pages a bit more often
• Give it a few weeks. You should see a nice :rocket: in the SERPs.

text: +1 on quotables and infographics. video or audio of key takeaways can be a good way to grab less reading inclined as well. also consider if some subsections or chapters could work as standalone blog posts or nurturing emails
